articles.headline: Growing Concern Over France’s Top Credit Rating Spreads Market Anxiety
articles.snippet: Shares of French financial institutions were hammered on mounting fears that France’s own sterling credit rating could be cut because of the European debt crisis.
articles.abstract: Shares of French financial institutions were hammered on mounting fears that France’s own sterling credit rating could be cut because of the European debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — With the sense of economic crisis deepening in Europe after the United States debt downgrade, investors have played Who’s Next with the shrinking list of nations that still hold the top rating of AAA. And their sights have landed on France.

articles.headline: Tiny Screens Bearing Tiny Delights
articles.snippet: Sifteo cubes offer a huge range of games through animation and gravity simulation. But one limitation remains to be overcome.
articles.abstract: Sifteo cubes offer a huge range of games through animation and gravity simulation. But one limitation remains to be overcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: Put Sifteo cubes in front of someone who’s never seen them before, and you’ll think somebody is reading the thesaurus. “Cool!” “Neat!” “Awesome!” “Serendipitous!”

articles.headline: U.S. Relies on Contractors in Somalia Conflict
articles.snippet: The American fight against extremists is being outsourced out of reluctance to send troops back into a country they hastily exited nearly two decades ago.
articles.abstract: The American fight against extremists is being outsourced out of reluctance to send troops back into a country they hastily exited nearly two decades ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Richard Rouget,  a gun for hire over two decades of bloody African conflict, is the unlikely face of the American campaign against militants in Somalia.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Banking Sector Punished Over European Debt
articles.snippet: Fears about the soundness of European banks are feeding new concerns about the stability of American financial institutions, whose shares have dived.
articles.abstract: Fears about the soundness of European banks are feeding new concerns about the stability of American financial institutions, whose shares have dived.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fear is on the rise again that worsening problems at some of Europe’s biggest banks may wind up hurting financial institutions in the United States.

articles.headline: Financial Turmoil Evokes Comparison to 2008 Crisis
articles.snippet: Stocks are plummeting. The economy is slowing. Politicians seek solutions but can’t agree. Is 2011’s turmoil a repeat of the financial crisis of 2008?
articles.abstract: Stocks are plummeting. The economy is slowing. Politicians seek solutions but can’t agree. Is 2011’s turmoil a repeat of the financial crisis of 2008?
articles.lead_paragraph: It feels eerily familiar: Stocks are plummeting. The economy is slowing. Politicians are scrambling to find solutions but are mired in disagreement.

articles.headline: It Zigs, It Zags: U.S. Market Rises 4% After a Down Day
articles.snippet: Markets continued this week’s pattern of wild swings between gains and losses, as earnings and jobless data got investors hunting for bargains.
articles.abstract: Markets continued this week’s pattern of wild swings between gains and losses, as earnings and jobless data got investors hunting for bargains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Continuing the wild swings from panicked selling to fevered buying and back, stocks soared on Thursday, leaving investors bewildered about what might come next.
articles.byline: By Floyd Norris and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: Four European Nations to Curtail Short-Selling
articles.snippet: The temporary move by France, Belgium, Italy and Spain will apply to trading in financial stocks in an effort to stop a tailspin in the markets.
articles.abstract: The temporary move by France, Belgium, Italy and Spain will apply to trading in financial stocks in an effort to stop a tailspin in the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: A European market regulator announced Thursday night that short-selling of stocks in several countries would be temporarily banned in an effort to stop the tailspin in the markets.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Stephen Castle
